awd_titl_txt: ADVANCE Adaptation: Diversity and Equity in Promotion, Tenure, and Hiring (DEPTH) for STEM Faculty
awd_abstract_narration:
The NSF ADVANCE program is designed to foster gender equity through a focus on the identification and elimination of organizational barriers that impede the full participation and advancement of diverse faculty in academic institutions.  Organizational barriers that inhibit equity may exist in policies, processes, practices, and the organizational culture and climate.  ADVANCE "Adaptation" awards provide support for the adaptation and adoption of evidence-based strategies to academic and non-academic non-profit organizations.

California State University, San Bernardino (CSUSB) will implement an ADVANCE Adaptation project named the Diversity and Equity in Promotion, Tenure and Hiring (DEPTH).  The DEPTH project will implement comprehensive policy changes concerning recruitment, hiring, and promotion and tenure.  In addition, the project will result in new processes and systems for data tracking and monitoring at the institution. CSUSB identified these areas of need through by reviewing institutional data and conducting surveys of faculty.  The CSUSB DEPTH project will adapt activities and strategies from the University of Arizona, University of Wisconsin, and University of Michigan's past ADVANCE Institutional Transformation projects to address CSUSB issues related to recruitment, hiring, promotion and tenure.  

The CSUSB project will result in: 1) A DEPTH Center at CSUSB; 2) A new data collection system to track applicant and faculty data; 3) Policies and trainings aimed at ensuring diverse applicant pools, effective faculty searches, and avoiding biases; and 4) More standardized faculty evaluation processes across the institution that promote equitable decision-making.   CSUSB is in an ideal position for the implementation of systematic change to address the issues of diversity in STEM faculty. CSUSB has undergone recent changes in administration and rapid student growth, and is about to enter a period of increased tenure-line faculty hires. A diverse faculty at CSUSB will reflect the student body which is primarily comprised of underrepresented and underserved populations in STEM including racial and ethnic minorities, women, and low SES students. In addition, CSUSB is part of the California State University 23 institution system, which is the largest university system in the USA and will be able to share and disseminate the content of its successful initiatives system-wide, potentially influencing the outcomes of over 13,000 faculty members.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The ADVANCE Adaptation: Diversity and Equity in Promotion, Tenure, and Hiring (DEPTH) for STEM Faculty (Award # 1760765) project was initiated to increase diversity and equity in the recruitment, hiring, retention, and advancement of faculty in STEM disciplines at California State University, San Bernardino (CSUSB). This overarching aim was demarcated by four primary goals, which served as the framework for the ADVANCE-DEPTH objectives and activities.

Goal 1: Establish a center for Diversity and Equity in Promotion, Tenure, and Hiring (DEPTH).

Activities: The DEPTH Center was established in Year 1 of the grant.

Objectives: Centralize, develop, and deliver empirically based faculty diversity, equity, and retention initiatives to a) increase and retain greater diversity in the faculty body, particularly in STEM departments and b) institutionalize successful ADVANCE-DEPTH initiatives.

Key Accomplishments: The DEPTH Center has been instrumental in developing and delivering a Best Practices in Faculty Searches training program, forming and facilitating retention, promotion, and tenure faculty learning communities, and generating policy and practice changes that incorporate best practices in faculty hiring and evaluation.

Goal 2: Develop comprehensive and sustainable data tracking systems.

Activities: In collaboration with Faculty Affairs and the Office of Institutional Research, the DEPTH team tracked diversity in tenure-line faculty hiring, equity in faculty compensation packages, and equity in faculty retention, promotion, and tenure outcomes (e.g., tenure and promotion decisions; salary increases). The team also tracked the gender and racial/ethnic composition of faculty search committees from 2017/18-2021/22.

Objectives: a) Identify and reduce gender and ethnic disparities in hiring and evaluating faculty and b) monitor success of DEPTH initiatives and use data-driven approach to modify and improve to maximize the effectiveness of initiatives.

Key Accomplishments: Tracking of compensation packages and tenure outcomes is now institutionalized by Academic Affairs.

Goal 3: Enact trainings and institute best practices that are directed at achieving diverse applicant pools, conducting effective faculty searches, and avoiding biases in the recruitment, hiring, and applicant evaluation processes.

Activities: We conducted an extensive review of past NSF ADVANCE work and the literature on best practices in faculty recruitment and hiring, which we curated into an open repository. We used the repository to develop a Best Practice in Faculty Hiring Guide, several best practical resources, and DEI training programs..

Objectives: Our objectives were to train 40% of the faculty body to stimulate the use of best DEI practices in faculty recruitment and hiring.

Key Accomplishments: We delivered our training sessions to 40% of the faculty over two years. Across the 4 years of the grant, there was a marked increase in the diversity of the tenure-line faculty body (e.g., STEM women assistant professors increased from 29% in 2017 to 39% and STEM URM women assistant professors from 2.5% to 10% in 2021) and compensation packages for newly hired faculty reached parity within both STEM and non-STEM departments.

Goal 4: Enact trainings and institute best practices that are directed at standardizing faculty evaluation processes to promote equitable decision-making in promotion and tenure.

Activities:

The DEPTH Team We facilitated faculty learning communities and worked with the Faculty Senate and Academic Affairs to increase DEI best practices in faculty evaluation and retention.

Key Accomplishments:

Promotion and tenure outcomes showed gender and racial/ethnic equity within both STEM and non-STEM departments. The representation of women, URM, and URM women faculty at the rank of full professor in STEM increased from 34.6% to 41.1%, 8.6% to 13.7%, and 1.2% to 4.1%, respectively.

Modified by: Donna M Garcia
